For anyone wondering why the decreased gravity on the flame's byproducts doesn't make the flame higher: buoyancy decreases with gravity, I think. Buoyancy is equal to the weight of volume displaced, and the weight of cold air is smaller in zero G. The flame byproducts don't rise as fast or at all, keeping the flame small.

1:36 - the man visible in the background, centre of image, is Jean-François Clervoy.
He has an oustanding career as a very experienced astronaut, with missions :
- Atlantis STS-66
- Atlantis STS-84
- Mir / NASA-4
- Discovery STS-103

He designed some of the STS cockpit displays, flight software, control interfaces... before acting similarly for the ISS. And also working on flight controls, satellites, automation systems, optical transmissions, man-machine interfaces, ATVs, etc.
He now stands as executive President of Novespace (the company operating those zero-G flights, subsidiary of the French CNES), after being their CEO for six years.
He is also parachutist, scuba-diver, plane pilot, university professor... enough said !

In the 1952 science fiction novel Islands in the Sky by Arthur C. Clarke, the protagonist becomes the butt of a practical joke on board a space station, as he is told to light a match to check the air. The match lights with a strange blueish round flame and then extinguishes, frightening him to thinking there is something wrong with the air. Turns out the air circulation had been turned off, and the match had used up the oxygen around it forming a bubble of CO₂. The joke perpetrator dryly notes that without air circulation on the station, that would tend to happen to the humans too and they'd get headaches from it…

I really hope we get LEO travel cheap enough that you can go and spend real time in microgravity. This is a good video, you are doing quite a bit in 20 second increments of 0 g, but I really want to see w hat happens when someone on a youtuber budget can get into orbit and stay there for a couple days.

Right now, getting into orbit is super expensive, so we have to focus our orbital dollars on getting the best research possible out of it. And unfortunately, research is kind of boring. The day to day on the ISS is important, but the time it takes to digest the interesting results are a lot less than the time it takes to gather that data and do the analysis.

I'm looking forward to the video you can do in the next 5 or so years where you get to go up there and take your time, set up demonstrations, execute them, fail, tweak the methodology, get it right, get it on film, and bring it back for all of us. I look forward even more to when we can all go up there for a vacation just to mess around. Until then, this is great, keep up the good work.

On 9/11 when the top 15 floors of the north tower started to fall, all that falling structural steel plus eventually all the 95 floors of structural steel below the collapse initiation point that those top floors crashed into, fell accelerating to the ground at a rate of 64% G. (1,368 feet tall in under 13 seconds) That means that all of the falling structural steel weighed 64% LESS then when before the planes crashed into the towers. There was no deceleration in the 3 building collapses of WTC1, WTC2, & WTC7.

Is Zero G really Zero G? Or is it traces of gravity (or even gravities)?

Trying to understand if the term is an oversimplification. From what I can understand, the sun pulls 28 G and makes our solar system possible. I guess the reason why humans stay on earth and don't get pulled by gravity into the sun is because of earth's gravity. I also understand that everything that has mass has its gravitational field.

But where I am not sure I understand the concept, is the relationship if the sun's gravity in this "tug war". Why the sun does not have an effect on me if I am in Zero G? Is it "my" mass? At what point am I in Zero G in space? If I am between venus and earth, am I impacted by any of those planet's gravity? Do I need to have a bigger mass in order to "feel" the pull?

So I guess I should ask at what point I am in Zero G and if mass my mass matter... Is everything in our universe is "pulled" by something? Our planet gravitate the sun, our solar system gravitates in the milky way and I have to imagine that galaxies gravitates too in some ways and who knows is there is something even bigger...

I guess I should try to search and find out but it seems like topic way too complex to digest for me.

To specify, zero g is not the same thing as no gravity. Zero g is a continuous freefall wherein gravitational force is cancelled out and not felt but still present. The ISS is actually experiencing zero g wherein it is continuously falling towards the earth, albeit the earth's rotation ensures that the station never enters the mesosphere where it would now be close enough to the earth to actually fall and crash. Gravity still has an appreciable albeit slight effect on the ISS, as orbital decay very gradually pulls the station down out of freefall and has to be corrected with extraneously applied force in order to retain zero g freefall orbit.

I think there is a second component to feeling weightless.  All of the force is causing a change in direction and not a change in speed.  You don't feel weightless while falling, you feel weightless when going over a hilltop in a car.  His marker in a bottle analogy is wrong.  Otherwise you would simple have the plane go into a steep dive to achieve weightlessness.  Instead, it goes into a path that is close to an orbit of the Earth.

It always bugs me when it’s suggested that no weight exists when inside the plane. E.G. “Weight is not a part of the equation” 6:40. 😆 You always have weight. Weight is mass multiplied by the force of gravity. Gravity always exists near a mass as big as the earth. The only thing shifting is the load. Load is relative and that’s what can shift because of angular momentum. We express load by comparing it to the standard load we normally experience from gravity without angular momentum (1G). High relative load (hyperG) and zero relative load (0G). 😇 two cents towards teaching proper science.

The moon - said to be 239,000 miles away from the earth - pulls on the oceans causing the tides; or so the song goes. Therefore, the aircraft & its' occupants are not outside of the gravitational pull of the earth; being just 5 miles above it. When the plane navigates in that zero-G mode, it could not possibly be negating gravity. Any more then a child nearing their upward motion on a swing is negating gravity.

Do you want to experience this plane ride and still do a really viable experiment? Do one that proves gravity exists in that plane - at the moment everything seems to be weightless. Because if gravity is real, then it is still present everywhere around & in that plane; even during an illusion where it appears that it isn't.

1.8G is substantial, but experiencing 7-9Gs is what I experience on a daily basis, and without a breathing technique that we are taught during training, doing 9G would be virtually impossible,
and in fighter jets, we are never advised to turn with the perpendicular force acting on the belly of the jet, as this creates negative Gs, and send blood from body into the head. This is impossible to prevent even with a full body muscle squeeze..
you would notice that all the fighter jets mostly turn always facing with the top of the fuselage “toward the turn”, it’s s difficult concept to explain in words, but yeah...

If you want to ever be a fighter pilot, under no circumstances do not even try negative Gs, I remember once I accidentally pulled -3G and was unable to continue flying so I had to RTB, the blood literally rushes up to your head in a split second and you get an instant “red-out”

So if you had a person who weighs in at 30 kilos in 0-G you would do 0.2 grams because hyper gravity is add 0.8 grams to 1 gram than 0-G would be 1 gram take away 0.8 which is 0.2 grams than the sum of that persons weight is 30 multiplied by 0.2 grams from the 0-G effect that persons body weight in 0-G is 6 kilos therefore in weightlessness you have a weight which for anyone who is exactly 30 kilograms is 6 kilograms and the weight for that 30 kilo person in hyper gravity is 30 multiplied by 1.8 which equals 54 so a persons weight in hyper gravity that in usual gravity is 30 kilos is 54 kilos. Dear Veritasium guy
That's not the only thing that appears counter-intuitive re: grav v no grav.
Everyone's been on that carnival ride that spins around really fast, centrifuging you to the walls, eventually allowing you to walk/ crawl around on the still vertical walls, right? I used to go on it again and again 'til I got sick. But anyway, a LOT of people out there and just about every single movie making team for every film ever set in space seem to think that if you rotated a section of a spacecraft or indeed, rotated the entire craft/ station that you could then use that same centrifugal force to pin you to the walls, thus simulating gravity.

This is a mistake. Such devices will do no such thing, and I sincerely hope that no space-pioneers are ever so absurdly short-sighted as to build something like this, assuming that because it works on Earth, that it would have the same effect in a micro-gravity environment. Exactly as you said: It seems counter-intuitive, but that's precisely because your/ our only frame of reference comes from living our lives in the polar opposite of weightlessness.

Now I've been on this rant for years. A number of times, I've contacted educators who had published these common-sense assumptions as fact, and after long and torturous debates, I've been able to show all of them that trying to use a centrifuge to simulate gravity in a weightless environment is factually incorrect/ it does not work. To their credit, each one who responded to me also published a corrected reprint. I was able to convince them because I can prove it.

I used to provide people with both a practical experiment they can perform and a thought experiment they could consider. However, this was sometimes more harm than help, as some people would ignore the practical experiment and just do the thought experiment. Once again, this goes back to what you said about weightlessness being counter-intuitive, because our entire experience is one where 'everything' is not weightless. Also, the examples of experiments I used to provide have changed over the years to try to find the one experiment that will best illustrate the results and will do so indisputably (also, the easier the experiment it to perform, the more likely someone is to actually do it).

To perform this experiment, find a carnival that has one of those spinning rooms they use as a centrifuge ride. Buy a helium balloon and a string. Now the next part is kinda fiddly, but any able-bodied person should have no trouble doing it. What you want to do, is to tie a counter-weight to the balloon, using the string (though you could tie wire to the balloon instead, and the weight of the wire could act as the counter balance, without needing to attach anything more). It's important the the lift of the balloon and the weight of the counter-weight is very closely balanced. You want the balloon to hover, without rising and without falling. For the final step, take the balloon into the ride, release it and watch what happens.

Now it's important that when you do this, the balloon is hovering. It's also important that the balloon is not touching anything inside the room and that when the room starts spinning, that nothing will come into contact with the balloon. The reason is because that balloon represents you as an astronaut, floating (technically free-falling) in space, with the room/ spaceship segment/ spaceship/ space station getting ready to start spinning around you to "simulate gravity".

If you perform this experiment, you will notice that the balloon continues to remain 'weightless' wherever it was placed, while the room proceeds to spin around it. And it doesn't matter how fast or how slowly the room is spinning, that helium balloon will continue to float imperiously through the air, oblivious to the failed attempt to 'simulate gravity' around it. I also have a potential solution for how one could actually simulate gravity in space, but I won't bother to go into more detail, unless you're actually interested in it.

Lastly, I can also give you a reasonably detailed explanation of the forces at work and why a centrifuge room/ segment doesn't work to simulate gravity in a weightless environment, but it looks like you have a reasonable grounding in physics. Perform the experiment (maybe $5- for a carnival ticket and another $2- for a few helium balloons) and it will be dare I say it intuitive to you what's going on.

Peace

I like your video, but I want to clarify how zero G is created on the plane. The aircraft flies a parabola, the velocity vector being tangent with the trajectory at each point, hence the velocity vector is constantly being rotated. The inertia of any object with mass opposes this change in the velocity vector orientation and is perceived by observers on the plane as a centrifugal force. If the centrifugal force is exactly one G, you feel weightless. The pilots control this G-factor with their flight controls. The most effective way is by pulling or pushing on the control yoke to tighten or loosen the curvature of the parabola, since throttling the engines takes too long to affect the aircraft's speed. So the true reason for zero G is the change of the orientation of the velocity vector of the aircraft that creates a mass inertia response. Not, as you exemplify using the bottle, the change in velocity vector magnitude as the aircraft accelerates towards the ground at 9.81 m/s^2. There is a change in velocity, but not that much or that quickly. The weightlessness occurs at the top part of the parabola, symmetrically before and after the apex. Not only on the downward leg after the apex.

I hope my input was helpful. I like your videos and enjoy having my intellect stimulated. Keep up the good work!

Here's how conditioned we are to live in a 1G gravity well: To show the effects of fire in Zero-G, the man in the blue/white jumpsuit should have held the lighter "upside down", to see the fire jet out towards what we perceive as "down".

His conditioning was telling him that the fire would burn his hand if held upside down, just as it would in a 1G environment... so he unconsciously held it "upright" to prevent the pain of a burn.

I have been on commercial flights a number of times over the years (strictly as a passenger). I have no problem with take-off and cruising, but it is turbulence and landing that [literally] make me white knuckled because of the sensation of sudden dropping. (I describe it as my stomach floating into my head, and the notion of being pulled down. That, plus a healthy fear of falling out of the sky to an early end, is why I also avoid roller coasters.)

In low/zero-G, there is no sense of up and down because our bodies are normally geared towards the pull of gravity.

That being said, I assume that in low/zero-G the disturbing sensation I feel when an airplane goes down is only magnified. Would this be accurate to say?

I can understand how the parabolic arc is counteracting the Earth's gravitational acceleration, because the arc creates a centripetal force that sort of nullifies the Earth gravity's force.

But... the weightless aspect of freefall (like the pen in the bottle) still confuses me. It reminds me of a trope in science fiction where you create an artificial gravitational attraction at the nose of the spaceship (using a rapidly evaporating miniature blackhole or whatever) and that pulls the ship forward. And you imagine that the crew would have their feet planted on the decks of the spaceship as their ship gets pulled forward.

But... as the bottle showed, if the gravitational acceleration was acting on the crewmembers and the rocket at the same time, the crew would float. It's weird, because the Earth has the special circumstance of inducing an acceleration on us, but it isn't moved by that acceleration. So we bump into the Earth and can't fall to the center of the Earth, which allows us to stand...

No. You don't get zero G when you accelerate. You get zero G when you stop accelerating and follow a straight line. Force equals mass times acceleration. The plane doesn't follow a parabolic. It follows a straight line. Even with respect to the accelerated reference frame of Earth, it's not a parabola. The Earth isn't flat. It's following an ellipse.
This stuff matters. You advertise that this channel tells the truth, so tell the truth, not a confusing "simplification". The lies you tell make it easy for you, but hard for your viewers.

The glowing part of a flame is just gas that is so hot it is incandescent, just like the tungsten filament in a light bulb.
The air outside the visible part of the flame is still very hot, it just isn't as hot as the part in the flame. That is ALL a flame really is, gas so hot it glows.
There are things that burn with no visible flame, and these things can be quite dangerous because you can't see the flame.
Watch a formula 1 race or Indy car race when they have a fire. Sometimes you might see a person jumping around. That person is actually on fire, and if he can't get someone's attention he or she can be quite badly burned.

Computer's Fly' our planes better than we ever can just ask. Capt. Chesley "Sully" Sullenberger who enjoyed the backup of computer autopilot during his famous "miracle on the Hudson" emergency landing in 2009. The stroke of genius in my opinion was his decision to activate the  APUs. These were originally known as putt–putts in WW2.. The B-29's DC power source in flight the putt-putt provided power for starting the main engines and was used after take-off to a height of 10,000 feet (3,000 m), the putt-putt was restarted when the B-29 was descending to land. The Boeing 727 in 1963 was the first jetliner to feature a gas turbine APU, allowing it to operate at smaller airports, independent from ground facilities. The APU can be identified on many modern airliners by an exhaust pipe at the aircraft's tail.
